DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Emerges From Coma in Time For Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Just last week, doctors thought 18-year-old Melissa ``Missy'' Goebel would remain in a coma for years. On Christmas Day, the Mead High School honors student was talking and watching as family members opened presents for her at Sacred Heart Medical Center. ``I thought the very best Christmas present I could ever get was to hear my daughter talk again,'' said Missy's father, Steve. ``She gave me that gift with a week to spare. And each day she gets a little bit better.'' Missy was injured Nov. 25 in a head-on collision on Interstate 90, just west of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. Ms. Goebel and her 16-year-old boyfriend were in her car when they collided with a pickup truck traveling the wrong way. Ian McElfish, the boyfriend, was treated and released. The 79-year-old driver of the pickup is now in a nursing home. A month ago, doctors, family members and friends thought Melissa would die. Missy was in a coma, largely unresponsive to talking and touching by family members. On Day 19, doctors said Goebel most likely would be comatose for years. But just a few hours after doctors left her room that day, Missy spoke to her mother. Then, she asked to telephone her brother, despite her head injuries and a broken neck, clavicle, right arm and left leg. ``She's a little miracle,'' said Victoria Goebel, Missy's mother. ``She's quite an amazing girl.'' Mrs. Goebel said she welcomed the sound of Missy bickering with her younger brother, Brian. ``She calls her brother a dweeb a lot,'' the mother said, adding that the siblings were close friends. ``I couldn't believe it when they were in there arguing the other day. It was great.'' Missy's struggle is far from over. The left side of her body remains paralyzed. Goebel said his daughter often slips into a ``kind of dream state'' and gets confused easily. ``She's pretty much like a rag doll,'' he said. ``But she's further along than anyone ever thought she would be.''
